column1: #text=Francine Kim, M.D.Children's Memorial Hospital  Abstract 3 mo.
#text=old male with seizures Keywords  Tuberous Sclerosis, MRI, brain
#text=old male with seizures   Findings  T1 weighted images demonstrate bilateral hyperintense subependymal nodules, the largest adjacent to the left Foramen of Monro.
#text=There are also multiple foci of hyperintensity within the subcortical and deep white matter.
#text=T2 weighted images demonstrate an area of cortical thickening and abnormal low signal within the anterior right temporal lobe.
#text=   Diagnosis  Tuberous Sclerosis    Differential For T1 hyperintense subependymal nodules: Germinal Matrix Hemorrhage.
#text=For cortical thickening with abnormal signal: Cortical dysplasia.

#text=The constellation of findings is specific for Tuberous Sclerosis     Discussion  Tuberous Sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable expressivity that demonstrates hamartomatous growths in multiple organ systems.
#text=The classic clinical triad of seizures, adenoma sebaceum and mental retardation is found in less than half of the patients.
#text=Therefore radiologic findings are very important in making the diagnosis.
#text=There are four major categories of intracranial lesions: 1.
#text=Cortical Tubers are cortical hamartomas found in 95% of patients with tuberous sclerosis.
#text=These demonstrate abnormally thick cortex and T1 hyperintensity and T2 hypointensity to premyelinated white matter in neonates and infants.
#text=In older children and adults the lesions are iso/hypointense on T1 images and hyperintense on T2 images.
#text=White matter abnormalities in a number of different patterns are usually identified.
#text=Like the cortical tubers these are usually hyperintense on T1WI and hypointense on T2WI in infants and iso/hypointense on T1WI and hyperintense on T2WI in older children and adults.
#text=Subependymal nodules are subependymal hamartomas found in 95% of patients with Tuberous Sclerosis.
#text=Most are located adjacent to the caudate nucleus just behind the foramen of Monro.
#text=These are typically hyperintense on T1WI and have variable signal on T2WI as they may calcify.
#text=Enhancement may be present and does not necessarily indicate neosplatic transformation.
#text=Subependymal giant cell tumors are present in 15% of patients with tuberous sclerosis.
#text=These are histologically benign tumors that enlarge over time.
#text=Usually they are located adjacent to the foramen of Monro and may cause obstructive hydrocephalus.
#text=They demonstrate intense but sometimes inhomogeneous enhancement and may calcify.
